title: 109_s3739
content: The Act may be cited as the "Consortium on the Impact of Technology in Aging Health Services Act of 2006" and establishes a Consortium. The "Consortium on the Impact of Technology in Aging Health Services" is established to evaluate new technologies for healthcare in response to demographic changes. It consists of 17 members appointed by the President, Senate Majority Leader, and Senate Minority Leader. The Consortium on the Impact of Technology in Aging Health Services consists of 17 members appointed by various leaders. Qualifications for appointments include experience in senior, geriatric, and assistive services, as well as technology development. The Consortium on the Impact of Technology in Aging Health Services appoints members from various sectors including technology developers, researchers, healthcare providers, insurers, and pharmaceutical industry representatives. At least 2 appointees must be aged 65 or older or individuals with disabilities. Appointments must be made within 30 days of the Act's enactment. The Consortium on the Impact of Technology in Aging Health Services appoints members for life, with vacancies filled within 30 days. The Consortium must hold an initial meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed, and meetings are called by the Chairperson. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for decision-making. SEC. 3. DUTIES. The Consortium will study new technology for older adults and caregivers, including identifying adaptable technology, fostering innovation, and addressing barriers to innovation in aging services technology. The Consortium will develop recommendations on identifying developments in aging services technology for increased efficiency and cost savings in the healthcare system. Opportunities for research and development in aging services technology include promoting independence, early disease detection, delaying decline, supporting wellness activities, and improving quality and efficiency of care. The curr_chunk discusses the need to enhance technology utilization in caregiving to reduce paperwork, minimize caregiver burnout, and improve medication compliance. It also addresses the importance of ensuring necessary technology infrastructure for aging services in rural and urban areas. Additionally, it considers the establishment of a Federal interagency task force and a National Resource Center for aging services technology development and distribution. The Consortium oversees projects and provides training for organizations offering aging services. Responsibilities for aging services are assigned based on jurisdiction, funding, and reporting relationships. A report with recommendations on national policy for technology and assistive health services for seniors is due within 24 months of the Act's enactment. The curr_chunk discusses the establishment of a National Resource Center on Aging Services Technologies to provide training and assistance for the application of technology in assistive health services for seniors. It also mentions legislative and program changes to support the private sector in developing consumer-empowered technology solutions. The curr_chunk discusses the powers granted in relation to the establishment of a National Resource Center on Aging Services Technologies. The Consortium established for the National Resource Center on Aging Services Technologies has the authority to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, use postal services, and enter into contracts for services. The Consortium for the National Resource Center on Aging Services Technologies can accept gifts, compensate agencies or individuals for services, and have the authority to take actions on behalf of the Consortium. They are also considered a committee of Congress for printing and binding purposes. SEC. 5. CONSORTIUM PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Consortium do not receive additional pay, allowances, or benefits. They are allowed travel expenses while performing duties. The Chairperson can appoint an executive director and necessary staff without following civil service laws. Compensation for the executive director is specified. The executive director of the Consortium is paid at level V of the Executive Schedule. Other staff are appointed under title 5, United States Code, and paid according to General Schedule pay rates. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Consortium without reimbursement. The Consortium's employees maintain civil service status without interruption. The Chairperson can procure temporary services at specified rates. The General Services Administration will provide office space for the Consortium's headquarters with necessary equipment. Authorization of appropriations for the Act is set at $1,500,000 for fiscal years 2007 through 2010. The Consortium will terminate 180 days after submitting the required report under section 3(c).
